title: 1920–21 Burnley F.C. season
text:
The 1920–21 season was the 32nd season of competitive <a href="association%20football">football</a> played by <a href="Burnley%20F.C.">Burnley Football Club</a>. Burnley began the season confidently, despite not having played a match for almost four months before their first league fixture of the season. After losing their first three games, Burnley embarked on a 30-match unbeaten league run from 4 September 1920 until 26 March 1921, winning the <a href="Football%20League%20First%20Division">Football League First Division</a> and becoming English champions for the first time in their history. Burnley's unbeaten run stood as a Football League record for over 80 years, until it was bettered by <a href="Arsenal%20F.C.">Arsenal</a> in the 2003–04 season. Burnley ended the 1920–21 season on 59 points, having won 23 games, drawn 13, and lost 6.
The team reached the third round of the <a href="FA%20Cup">FA Cup</a>, defeating <a href="Leicester%20City%20F.C.">Leicester City</a> away and <a href="Queens%20Park%20Rangers%20F.C.">Queens Park Rangers</a> at home, before unexpectedly losing away to Second Division side <a href="Hull%20City%20A.F.C.">Hull City</a>. Burnley won the East Lancashire Charity Cup, beating <a href="Blackburn%20Rovers%20F.C.">Blackburn Rovers</a> 8–2 over two legs, but fared poorly in the <a href="Lancashire%20Senior%20Cup">Lancashire Senior Cup</a>, losing to <a href="Manchester%20City%20F.C.">Manchester City</a>. As league champions, Burnley qualified for the <a href="FA%20Community%20Shield">Charity Shield</a>, in which they were beaten 0–2 by <a href="FA%20Cup">FA Cup</a> winners <a href="Tottenham%20Hotspur%20F.C.">Tottenham Hotspur</a>. Burnley also played two <a href="exhibition%20match">friendly matches</a> during the season. The first, against Blackburn Rovers, marked the opening of <a href="Accrington%20Stanley%20F.C.">Accrington Stanley</a>'s new stadium; the other was a benefit match for <a href="Patsy%20Gallacher">Patsy Gallacher</a>, against a representative team from the <a href="Scottish%20Football%20League">Scottish Football League</a>.
Burnley used 23 different players during the season and had nine different goalscorers. Their top scorer was Scottish forward <a href="Joe%20Anderson%20%28Scottish%20footballer%29">Joe Anderson</a>, with 31 competitive goals, including 25 in the league. Eight new players were signed by Burnley during the course of the season, and nine were released. Match attendances were the highest they had ever been at <a href="Turf%20Moor">Turf Moor</a>, with an average gate of over 30,000. The highest attendance of the campaign was a crowd of 42,653, who saw Burnley beat <a href="Bolton%20Wanderers%20F.C.">Bolton Wanderers</a> 3–1 on 26 February 1921; the lowest was 22,000, for the match against Sunderland on the final day of the season.
Background and pre-season.
The 1920–21 campaign was the second season of competitive football in England after the First World War. Burnley's chairman, Harry Windle, had been elected to the position in 1909, and manager <a href="John%20Haworth">John Haworth</a> was marking his 11th consecutive year in charge. After finishing as runners-up to <a href="West%20Bromwich%20Albion%20F.C.">West Bromwich Albion</a> in the <a href="Football%20League%20First%20Division">Football League First Division</a> the previous season, there was a sense of eager anticipation within the club before the season began. Team captain <a href="Tommy%20Boyle%20%28footballer%20born%201886%29">Tommy Boyle</a> claimed that his side was capable of building on its success of the previous season and winning the league championship, despite Burnley not having won a trophy since their <a href="FA%20Cup">FA Cup</a> victory in 1914.
Burnley did not play any pre-season <a href="exhibition%20match">friendly</a> games other than a practice match between the first team and the reserves, which was watched by a crowd of around 10,000 at Turf Moor. The team's last competitive match had ended in a 0–2 defeat against <a href="Manchester%20United%20F.C.">Manchester United</a> in the <a href="Lancashire%20Senior%20Cup">Lancashire Senior Cup</a> on 8 May 1920, almost four months earlier. The <a href="Kit%20%28association%20football%29">strip</a> for 1920–21 was very little changed from that of the previous season; the claret jersey with light blue sleeves and a light blue stripe around the collar was kept along with the white shorts, but the claret socks were replaced by black.
Transfers.
The nucleus of the Burnley team remained unchanged from the previous campaign. Eight new players signed for the club, and eleven left during the season. New signings included goalkeeper <a href="Frank%20Birchenough">Frank Birchenough</a> from <a href="West%20Ham%20United%20F.C.">West Ham United</a> and defender <a href="Bob%20McGrory">Bob McGrory</a> from <a href="Dumbarton%20F.C.">Dumbarton</a>. Also brought in were <a href="George%20Richardson%20%28footballer%20born%201901%29">George Richardson</a> from <a href="non-league%20football">non-league</a> side Horden Athletic and <a href="Tom%20Brophy">Tom Brophy</a> from <a href="St%20Helens%20Town%20F.C.">St Helens Town</a>. <a href="West%20Bromwich%20Albion%20F.C.">West Bromwich Albion</a>'s <a href="Len%20Moorwood">Len Moorwood</a> was also signed in October 1920 to provide further goalkeeping backup. Attackers <a href="Richard%20Cragg">Richard Cragg</a>, <a href="Billy%20Clarkson">Billy Clarkson</a> and <a href="Patrick%20Norris%20%28footballer%29">Patrick Norris</a> were among those who left the club in pre-season. Defender <a href="Tom%20Bamford">Tom Bamford</a>, who had not played a match for Burnley since before the First World War thanks to the emergence of <a href="Len%20Smelt">Len Smelt</a>, also left the club and joined <a href="Rochdale%20A.F.C.">Rochdale</a> in September 1920.
Transfer activity continued after the season began. Inside forward <a href="Jack%20Lane">Jack Lane</a> was brought in from <a href="Cradley%20Heath%20F.C.">Cradley Heath</a> in December 1920, followed by defender <a href="John%20Pearson%20%28footballer%20born%201896%29">John Pearson</a> from the same club two months later. Winger <a href="George%20Douglas%20%28footballer%29">George Douglas</a> was signed from <a href="Leicester%20City%20F.C.">Leicester City</a> in February 1921. <a href="Thomas%20Jackson%20%28footballer%2C%20born%201896%29">Thomas Jackson</a>, who had made only one first-team appearance for Burnley, left the club in January 1921 to sign for Scottish side <a href="Dundee%20F.C.">Dundee</a>. Two players who had been signed at the beginning of the season left Burnley in April 1921; Bob McGrory moved to <a href="Stoke%20City%20F.C.">Stoke City</a> on a free transfer and Frank Birchenough was released after playing two league matches. <a href="Bert%20Freeman">Bert Freeman</a> left Burnley at the end of the season after nine years service, by which time he had become the club's all-time leading goalscorer.

League campaign.
Burnley's league campaign began on 28 August 1920 with a home match against <a href="Bradford%20City%20A.F.C.">Bradford City</a>, who had finished 15th in the league in 1919–20. The season began inauspiciously for Burnley, beaten 1–4, but the match did see eventual top scorer Joe Anderson score the first of his 25 league goals of the campaign. Two further away defeats followed, 0–1 at <a href="Huddersfield%20Town%20A.F.C.">Huddersfield Town</a> and 0–2 at Bradford City, leaving Burnley at the bottom of the league table. This run of defeats was Burnley's worst start to a league season since 1906–07, when they also lost their opening three matches. Manager Haworth subsequently made several changes to the team; goalkeeper <a href="Jerry%20Dawson%20%28footballer%20born%201888%29">Jerry Dawson</a> and defender <a href="Tommy%20Boyle%20%28footballer%20born%201886%29">Tommy Boyle</a> were reinstated, while <a href="Bert%20Freeman">Bert Freeman</a> and <a href="James%20Lindsay%20%28footballer%29">James Lindsay</a> were dropped in favour of <a href="Billy%20Nesbitt">Billy Nesbitt</a> and <a href="Benny%20Cross">Benny Cross</a> respectively. Burnley picked up their first win on 6 September 1920, beating Huddersfield Town 3–0 at <a href="Turf%20Moor">Turf Moor</a>; the goalscorers were <a href="Bob%20Kelly%20%28footballer%29">Bob Kelly</a>, Tommy Boyle, and Billy Nesbitt. They went on to defeat <a href="Middlesbrough%20F.C.">Middlesbrough</a> 2–1 at home, and to draw with them 0–0 at <a href="Ayresome%20Park">Ayresome Park</a>. On 25 September 1920, four players scored in a 4–0 victory against a weakened <a href="Chelsea%20F.C.">Chelsea</a> team, giving Burnley their third successive home win.
October began with a 1–1 draw with Chelsea at <a href="Stamford%20Bridge%20%28stadium%29">Stamford Bridge</a>, after which the team recorded four straight wins throughout the remainder of the month. Burnley achieved home and away victories against <a href="Bradford%20Park%20Avenue%20A.F.C.">Bradford (Park Avenue)</a>, before repeating the feat in the next two matches against <a href="Tottenham%20Hotspur%20F.C.">Tottenham Hotspur</a>. Burnley beat Tottenham 2–1 on 23 October 1920, then achieved a 2–0 victory the following week, the first time in the season that any team had been able to prevent Tottenham from scoring in a league match. The team's performance at <a href="White%20Hart%20Lane">White Hart Lane</a> was met with disapproval from the correspondent from the "<a href="Daily%20Mail">Daily Mail</a>", who wrote that Burnley set out to stifle their opponents and in doing so "spoilt the match". Burnley carried on their winning streak into November, with goals from Bob Kelly, Tommy Boyle and Benny Cross helping the side to defeat <a href="Newcastle%20United%20F.C.">Newcastle United</a> 3–1 at home and 2–1 away to lift them to second place in the league. The home fixture was marred by tragedy when a charabanc transporting supporters from <a href="Grassington">Grassington</a> overturned, killing five people. After the next game, a 2–2 draw with <a href="Oldham%20Athletic%20A.F.C.">Oldham Athletic</a> at <a href="Boundary%20Park">Boundary Park</a> on 20 November 1920, Burnley moved to the top of the table on goal average, 11 weeks after having been at the bottom. In the return match at Turf Moor a week later, Oldham were comfortably beaten 7–1; Bob Kelly scored four goals, and the others were added by Tommy Boyle and Benny Cross.
A win and a draw against <a href="Liverpool%20F.C.">Liverpool</a>, followed by a 2–0 victory over <a href="Preston%20North%20End%20F.C.">Preston North End</a>, took Burnley into the Christmas period three points clear at the top of the league. The convincing 6–0 win over <a href="Sheffield%20United%20F.C.">Sheffield United</a> on Christmas Day, in which forward <a href="Joe%20Anderson%20%28Scottish%20footballer%29">Joe Anderson</a> scored four times, set a new club record unbeaten streak of 17 games, beating the record set during the 1897–98 campaign. Burnley continued their good form into 1921, beating Preston North End away before achieving two victories against local rivals <a href="Blackburn%20Rovers%20F.C.">Blackburn Rovers</a>. The first of these wins, a 4–1 success, was watched by 41,534 spectators, the biggest home crowd of the season until then. The victory was followed by a 3–1 away win a week later. On 5 February 1921, Anderson scored five goals in a "brilliant" performance against <a href="Aston%20Villa%20F.C.">Aston Villa</a> as Burnley recorded their second 7–1 win of the season. The result saw Burnley equal the <a href="The%20Football%20League">Football League</a> record of 22 matches unbeaten, held by Sheffield United and Preston North End. A new league unbeaten record was set with a 0–0 draw with Aston Villa four days later. Despite losing George Halley to an illness which forced him to miss the remainder of the season, Burnley secured a late home win over <a href="Derby%20County%20F.C.">Derby County</a> in the following game, sending Derby to the bottom of the league table. February ended with a 3–1 victory against <a href="Bolton%20Wanderers%20F.C.">Bolton Wanderers</a> in front of a crowd of 42,653, the largest league attendance ever at Turf Moor at the time. The team took four points from the next three matches. Burnley firstly drew 1–1 away against a Bolton Wanderers team who were unbeaten at home, before a then-record crowd of 54,609 at <a href="Burnden%20Park">Burnden Park</a>, before beating <a href="Arsenal%20F.C.">Arsenal</a> at Turf Moor. The following week Burnley secured an away draw at Arsenal, despite their opponents attacking for much of the game.
A late Benny Cross goal gave Burnley a 1–0 win over <a href="Manchester%20United%20F.C.">Manchester United</a> at Turf Moor, extending the team's unbeaten record to 30 matches. In the next match, Burnley lost a league fixture for the first time since 4 September 1920 when they were beaten 0–3 by <a href="Manchester%20City%20F.C.">Manchester City</a> at <a href="Hyde%20Road%20Football%20Stadium">Hyde Road</a>. City were also challenging for the league title and eventually finished as runners-up. More than 37,000 spectators attended the match and several people were injured as the stadium became overcrowded. Burnley followed up the setback with successive wins over Manchester City and Manchester United to take the total number of league wins in the season to 23. The team suffered its fifth league defeat of the campaign on 9 April 1921, losing 0–2 away at <a href="West%20Bromwich%20Albion%20F.C.">West Bromwich Albion</a>.
Burnley played West Bromwich Albion again seven days later, drawing 1–1. The team went into the match against <a href="Everton%20F.C.">Everton</a> on 23 April 1921 needing a draw to clinch the league championship. Everton took the lead 15 minutes into the game, but Benny Cross scored the equalising goal three minutes later, and Burnley held on to become English champions for the first time in their history. Local newspapers were effusive in their praise of the Burnley side, calling them "the greatest team that ever was". The draw with Everton was succeeded by another 1–1 stalemate against the same team at Turf Moor. In the penultimate game, Burnley were beaten 0–1 away at <a href="Sunderland%20A.F.C.">Sunderland</a>, their sixth and final league defeat of the season. The campaign ended with a 2–2 draw against Sunderland on 7 May 1921 in front of a season-lowest crowd of 22,000. The draw took Burnley to a tally of 59 points, five points clear of second-placed Manchester City, and one short of West Bromwich Albion's then-record total of 60 points set in <a href="1919%E2%80%9320%20Football%20League">1919–20</a>.
At half time during the final match of the season, the championship trophy was paraded around the Turf Moor pitch accompanied by a marching band. After the full-time whistle was blown, supporters swarmed the pitch to celebrate the team's success. The Football League president, <a href="John%20McKenna">John McKenna</a>, made the official presentation of the trophy to the Burnley captain Boyle and congratulated the side on their achievement, particularly praising "their splendid training and their beautiful football". Medals were awarded to the manager John Haworth, the club trainer Charlie Bates and the eleven players who had featured in the match against Sunderland. Three more medals were later awarded to Mosscrop, Taylor and Basnett.
Other first team matches.
Burnley's first match outside the league in the 1920–21 season was a <a href="exhibition%20match">friendly</a> on 22 September 1920 against a <a href="Blackburn%20Rovers%20F.C.">Blackburn Rovers</a> XI to mark the opening of <a href="Accrington%20Stanley%20F.C.%20%281891%29">Accrington Stanley</a>'s new stadium at Peel Park. Burnley won the game 10–1 with seven goals from Joe Anderson in addition to strikes from James Lindsay, Walter Weaver and Thomas Jackson. Burnley's opening game in the <a href="FA%20Cup">FA Cup</a> was an away tie at <a href="Leicester%20City%20F.C.">Leicester City</a> on 8 January 1921. Bob Kelly scored for the fourth game in succession and Joe Anderson scored four goals as Burnley won the match 7–3, the first time the team had scored seven goals in a competitive match away from home. After the match, the "<a href="Athletic%20News">Athletic News</a>" described Burnley as the best team in the country.
Following the win over Leicester City, Burnley were drawn against <a href="Queens%20Park%20Rangers%20F.C.">Queens Park Rangers</a> at Turf Moor in the Second Round. Despite a good performance by their opponents, Burnley progressed to the Third Round with a 4–2 win, in which Bob Kelly struck twice in the first half and Joe Anderson scored either side of half time. In the Third Round, Burnley were handed an away tie at <a href="Hull%20City%20A.F.C.">Hull City</a>, who at the time were struggling in the <a href="Football%20League%20Second%20Division">Football League Second Division</a> and had won only two matches in the previous five months. Despite being without first-team regulars <a href="George%20Halley">George Halley</a> and Joe Anderson through injury, Burnley were expected to win comfortably, not having lost since 4 September 1920. Hull City played above all expectations and Burnley suffered a 0–3 defeat after being 0–1 behind at half time.
In April 1921, Burnley won the East Lancs Charity Cup for the second consecutive season, beating Blackburn Rovers 8–2 on aggregate over two legs. The first leg was won 6–2 at Turf Moor thanks to goals from <a href="Eddie%20Mosscrop">Eddie Mosscrop</a>, Joe Anderson, Benny Cross and a <a href="hat-trick">hat-trick</a> from Bob Kelly, before strikes from Joe Anderson and James Lindsay gave Burnley a 2–0 win at <a href="Ewood%20Park">Ewood Park</a>. This success was followed by a 2–1 friendly victory over a <a href="Scottish%20Football%20League%20XI">Scottish Football League XI</a> in a benefit match for <a href="Celtic%20F.C.">Celtic</a> winger <a href="Patsy%20Gallacher">Patsy Gallacher</a>. Burnley also participated in the <a href="Lancashire%20Senior%20Cup">Lancashire Senior Cup</a>; the league matches against Blackburn Rovers and Preston North End also counted as group stage matches in the competition. The team won all four of these games to qualify for the semi-finals, where they were drawn against <a href="Manchester%20City%20F.C.">Manchester City</a>. The game on 9 May 1921 ended in a 0–2 defeat for Burnley, and their opponents went on to win the trophy that year.
As champions of the Football League, Burnley qualified for the <a href="FA%20Community%20Shield">Charity Shield</a>, then known as the Dewar Shield. Burnley's opponents were <a href="Tottenham%20Hotspur%20F.C.">Tottenham Hotspur</a>, who had finished sixth in the First Division and beaten <a href="Wolverhampton%20Wanderers%20F.C.">Wolverhampton Wanderers</a> in the FA Cup final. In what was the last match of the 1920–21 campaign, Burnley fell to a 0–2 loss at <a href="White%20Hart%20Lane">White Hart Lane</a> on 16 May 1921. The match was not without controversy, as the Burnley players claimed that the second goal should have been disallowed despite the Tottenham goalscorer being <a href="offside%20%28association%20football%29">onside</a>, maintaining that the whistle had already been blown by the referee.
Player details.
Burnley <a href="manager%20%28football%29">manager</a> <a href="John%20Haworth">John Haworth</a> used 23 different players during the 1920–21 season, and there were nine different goalscorers. The team played in a 2–3–5 formation throughout the campaign, with two <a href="fullback%20%28association%20football%29">fullbacks</a>, three <a href="Wing%20half">halfbacks</a>, two <a href="outside%20forward">outside forward</a>s, two <a href="inside%20forward">inside forward</a>s and a <a href="centre%20forward">centre forward</a>. <a href="Billy%20Watson%20%28footballer%20born%201890%29">Billy Watson</a> played the highest number of games, appearing in all 45 First Division and FA Cup matches. <a href="Billy%20Nesbitt">Billy Nesbitt</a> and <a href="Joe%20Anderson%20%28Scottish%20footballer%29">Joe Anderson</a> each played 43 times. Anderson was the top goalscorer for Burnley in the campaign with 31 competitive goals, including 25 in the league, the highest total since <a href="Bert%20Freeman">Bert Freeman</a>'s 36 goals in 1912–13. With a tally of 23 goals, <a href="Bob%20Kelly%20%28footballer%29">Bob Kelly</a> was the second-highest scorer, followed by <a href="Benny%20Cross">Benny Cross</a> with 15, including the goal that won the title for Burnley. Club captain <a href="Tommy%20Boyle%20%28footballer%20born%201886%29">Tommy Boyle</a> was the highest-scoring defender, with seven goals in 38 league appearances. Winger Billy Nesbitt scored five times during the season.
<a href="England%20national%20football%20team">England</a> international goalkeeper <a href="Jerry%20Dawson%20%28footballer%20born%201888%29">Jerry Dawson</a> missed three games, two because of an injury sustained in the opening match. Centre forward Bert Freeman, who had become the first ever Burnley player to score 100 league goals, and held the club record for most goals in a season, played only four matches. His final appearance for Burnley came in the FA Cup Third Round defeat to Hull City. Several players made bit-part contributions to the campaign; <a href="Tom%20Brophy">Tom Brophy</a> and <a href="Bob%20McGrory">Bob McGrory</a> each made just three first-team appearances and <a href="Frank%20Birchenough">Frank Birchenough</a>, <a href="George%20Douglas%20%28footballer%29">George Douglas</a>, <a href="Jack%20Lane">Jack Lane</a>, <a href="Len%20Moorwood">Len Moorwood</a> and <a href="Bill%20Taylor%20%28footballer%20born%201886%29">Bill Taylor</a> played in two matches or fewer. <a href="George%20Richardson%20%28footballer%20born%201901%29">George Richardson</a> and <a href="John%20Pearson%20%28footballer%20born%201896%29">John Pearson</a>, both new signings in the 1920–21 season, failed to make a first-team appearance for Burnley during the campaign. <a href="Thomas%20Jackson%20%28footballer%2C%20born%201896%29">Thomas Jackson</a> was a squad member until January 1921, but he did not play any games for Burnley in the 1920–21 campaign.

Aftermath.
The Burnley board had planned a tour of Spain to take place during the summer of 1921 after the culmination of the league campaign. However, the trip had to be cancelled when the club received notice from the <a href="Spanish%20Football%20Federation">Spanish Football Federation</a> that one of their intended opponents, <a href="Barcelona%20CF">Barcelona</a>, had been suspended from all matches. Further tours of Norway and France were then arranged, but these also had to be abandoned after <a href="the%20Football%20Association">the Football Association</a> refused to grant permission. At the end of the season five players were given free transfers by the club; Len Smelt and Frank Birchenough, who had both played for Burnley during the campaign, and three reserve players. Moreover, two players–Bert Freeman and <a href="George%20Thompson%20%28footballer%20born%201895%29">George Thompson</a>–were placed on the <a href="transfer%20list">transfer list</a> by the manager.
Burnley's 30-game unbeaten streak during the 1920–21 season stood as a Football League record for 83 years until it was surpassed by Arsenal, who completed the entire season without losing in the 2003–04 campaign. After the defeat to Bradford City on 28 August 1920, Burnley did not lose another match at Turf Moor until 11 February 1922, when they were beaten 1–2 by Blackburn Rovers. In the same match, the halfback line of Tommy Boyle, George Halley and Billy Watson—used in 25 first-team games during 1920–21—was seen for the final time, having played together for the first time in September 1913. The majority of the championship-winning team remained intact going into the 1921–22 season, although players such as David Taylor and Walter Weaver found themselves less involved in first-team matches.
